reviewText: 3/10\nAs much as I love the spiritual successor Guns of Icarus, this game is just s**t. It's buggy to all hell, the gameplay is repetitive and boring, and there's no story. It's got the right idea but goes nowhere with it. I picked this up at $0.50, and even that felt like too much for this unpolished lump of coal. It needs a lot more story, mechanics and variety before it's worth anyone's time, and the team has given up on it, so strongly discourage you from buying it. I highly recommend the multiplayer sequel, however, so go play that.
voteText: 33 of 42 people (79%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is bad.

The concept is okay. It's like Guns of Icarus.
The problem lay mainly with the fact that the game only lets you play the first level. It's glitchy and simply won't let you interact with your guns in level 2 - and before you think this was a personal problem this was something I found to be the case after watching a video review on youtube as well. The game simply doesn't have anything past level 1 (which is only about 5 minutes long).

The ship you fly in looked like something a 4 year old designed and a 12 year old built. The cannons had some effort in them. The rest of the graphics honestly felt like the maker had no desire to make it a good game. It seriously gave me the I don't care if it looks bad. I just plan to make a fast buck" impression. These are the graphics you would see on those computer games from the early 90s where 3D is still a bit of a workout. Not today if you're actually expecting people to pay for the game.
Anyone that has played Second Life: You could make the majority of this ship exactly recreated in prim and texture (from scratch) in about 1 minute on SL. It was really that simplistically designed (guns aside).

The animations were about the same. Not that I saw many inside 5 minutes. They felt like someone rushed them out as some free favor they owed the developer.

I started this game more or less expecting a single player mode of Guns of Icarus - a reasonable thing to asume considering when I first got it the game was named "Guns of Icarus" (barely any different than "Guns of Icarus Online"). I was honestly interested to see what they had in mind for a solo adventure. A story where you fight against AI opponents like many single player games. That sounds awesome really since I like GoI.
It didn't have anything like that. Just a blocky albiet fun 5 minute fight against some planes followed by the inability to actually do anything for the rest of the levels.

This game gets an actual 0/10.Possibly the only game I would ever rate so low."

reviewText: I loved Guns of Icarus Online but this game is no where near as good. I only bought it because I wanted to collect all the games in the series. However, this is expected as it was released in 2010 and was pretty much a little prototype to Guns of Icarus and I didn't expect it to be great. I bought it for less than a dollar so I can't really complain. That being said, I'm curious why the developers kept this on Steam as those who have never played Guns of Icarus Online might think that it is similar to Flight of the Icarus and shun Guns of Icarus Online when it is in fact an amazing game.

reviewText:
tl;dr, detailed review below+ It's a nice minigame
+ Upgrades for your airship

-- Need to restart the game to play the second mission.
-- Quality/price ratio
-- Linear and very repetitive gameplay
- Only 4 enemy types
- No story other than the explanation on the shop site


Gameplay
In Flight of the Icarus" you're playing a privateer who owns an airship with multiple guns on it to shoot enemy aircrafts. That's basically it. Your airship holds 5 guns
date:
which you can upgrade at the start of each level if you have enough points.


Scenario
Flight of the Icarus is like an oldschool shoot-em-up
recommended: but worse. Every level works the same way: You wait until you see enemies (pirates) flying towards you. Usually you're faster finding them by looking around than focusing on your radar. Your task is quite simple: shoot them. If you don't manage to shoot them fast enough
hoursPlayed: they hit your ship and damage some parts of it. But don't worry
voteText: you can run around and fix everything. The only thing changing between the levels are the guns you place and the weather. The main character doesn't take any damage.\n\nOn your HUD there's a timer telling you how long you have to survive. After the countdown hits zero the level immediately stops
helpfulPercent: even if there are enemies left around you. After each level you get points
votesHelpful: depending on how much cargo you have left and how many enemies you've shot. If you have enough points you'll get a new weapon which you can place on your ship. There are only 4-6 spots
votesTotal: so you usually have to replace other weapons.\n\nThere's also a survival mode
votesFunny:
where you need to defend your airship as long as possible.


Key features
Unlock the Fallen Hero Cap in Guns of Icarus Online ...

Guns of Icarus Online is a Multiplayer which costs 20$. I don't own it
commentsCount:
so I can't tell something about it.

18 Epic Levels & 8 Powerful Guns

They're not epic
column16: but linear. The guns are quite nice though.\n\n4 Enemy Types (Duster
column19: and Airship)\n\nThey won't be stronger if you choose a medium or hard level
column20:
there will only be more of them.

Time of Day & Weather Effects

As mentioned
column21:
that's the only thing changing between the levels.


Overall Quality
Graphics:
The game has a steampunkt design
column23:
it doesn't look too bad. Remember it's an Indie Game.

Sound:
There are only basic sounds (shooting
column25:
not much more to mention.

Weapons:
There are 8 weapons (more than enemies!). Every weapon behaves different.

Enemies:
There are 4 enemy types. There is a boss fight in which you have to beat multiple airships.

Coop:
?? Afaik the Coop doesn't work anymore. But I'm not sure on that one - I don't know anyone else who has this game.


Known Issues
You usually won't be able to play after beating the first level. To continue the "story" you have to restart the game.


Worth the price?
Definitely not. The game is quite fun to play once in a while
column26: but it's not worth more than 0.99$. Check out Steam Sales if you want to buy this game."

reviewText:
In 'Flight Of The Icarus you're in command of your own Airship. You're character has to walk around the ship and take controll of different guns to take out the incoming enemies and repair parts of your ship that has been damaged.

After you've survived a level you can place different guns (turrets, canons etc.), upgrade your armor or add some crew to your ship.

Since there's no real story or online option, Flight Of The Icarus gets boring pretty quick. It's not a bad game but I would recommend getting Guns Of Icarus" which is more expensive but has multiplayer.
"

reviewText: This was the only good game in the Groupees Be Mine Bundle 4 (which included such sterling luminaries as two dead multiplayer-only games and ♥♥♥♥ing Revelations 2012). The reason it looks so stodgy is because it was developed by four programmers over four months on a budget I think was around four hundred dollars. Despite the punk rock style development and a campaign that will last you two hours if you take the most circuitous route, giving those pirate ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s what for and then nipping off to fix up the ship before round two of the great punchup in the sky is ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic! I haven't tried multiplayer, because I'm expecting it to be dead or full of turds, but Guns of Icarus Online is going to be coming very soon and is something you should keep your eye on.

reviewText: This small indie game screams one trick pony from the screenshots, but it's a good trick if you're an airship junkie like me. The single player campaign has you running to different types of guns, then repairing parts of the ship during lulls...almost like a tower defense where you're playing the towers. Multiplayer adds crew to your ship, and a greyed out option for additional campaigns is making me cross my fingers. I bought this more as a duty to my newfound love of steampunk, but I was surprised how good the game actually is. Try a demo if one's available.\n\nUpdate: The sequel/online version has since been released, with a big focus on multiplayer. I haven't gotten to try it just yet but can only imagine that it makes this older game more or less obsolete.

reviewText: Protect your zeppelin, upgrade or replace your on-board weapons and shoot down as many planes as you can before time runs out or before they destroy your cargo. It's a form of tower defense, but very basic and easy. After each level you have the opportunity to add new weapons or replace existing ones with unlocked or upgraded guns. The graphics look poor and there's practically no sound (the thunder and guns are the only sounds that come to mind actually). I wouldn't really recommend it to anyone.\n\n[Rating: 65/100]

reviewText:
It is a cheap rip off of guns of Icarus. If you want to get guns of Icarus please do I have that game as well and find it unbelievably fun. This game is terrible though.
You are set in an airship then expected to keep it flying without any assistance while hoards of enemies shoot at you.
I do not even know if the game is winnable because lord knows it is difficult, but it is too shallow to reward you for your troubles.
I don't mind difficult games, (undertale genocide run / darksouls / and other such games are actually fun to me), but the idea is that the diffculty is with reason and afterwards there is a sence that you advanced and got better. here its just a bland rip off with no substance.
So if you are a fan of shooting yourself in the foot for NO REASON. please do play this game. If your the kind of person that wants to shoot themself in the foot because you like the challenge of walking around with lead in your foot try elsewhere.

EDIT:
The game is still not able to be recommended. It is a boring grindy mess with little reward.
It keeps the player running arround trying to do everything by themselves including keeping the ship repaired and running and defending itself form hostiles. At first this is not bad and is quite relaxing but as the difficult increases it becomes stressful. As mentioned above I do not mind stress if I get a feeling of reward afterwards, but this one has no sence of reward in it. You completed a mission and your reward is a type of gun. This means that you have to grind in order to advacne. and Again grinding is not something I am against, but I need to see the grind advancing me. In most RPGs when you grind you can see your character getting stronger and more powerful. but in this game the grind is so slow and near negligable it becomes a chore. I can kill the same wave on enemies 100 times but never feel like i get better. Am I getting better or stronger, sorta  again the guns help, but it feel so small that I never get that feeling like I am stronger.
The game is not in of itself bad, but it is dull as dirt. It lacks any real depth. I don't mind a single player game (actually i prefure them) but there needs to be something there to entertain me. A story, A character, just something. There really is nothing here to keep me going.
It feels like this game is now just a pointless void. Get Guns of Iccaraus. It is what this game wants to be. Still no story, but it replaces it with multiplayer.
I feel this game should be removed from the steam store. It no longer serves a purpose. It fails to entertain, the one purpose of a game.

reviewText: Guns of Icarus is a game that places you aboard an airship with many mounted gatling guns which you must run back and forth between to shoot down incoming planes. The graphics are surprisingly good for a game that is only 85 MB, but the music is a little too somber for my tastes. The washed out sepia tones for me, also added to the boredom a bit. However the game does feature a long campaign, unlockable upgrades as well as some tactical strategizing. Both the Steam Overlay and widescreen resolutions are supported.  For the price, Guns of Icarus may have some appeal for mainstream audiences, but the gameplay is not compelling enough to be called addicting.

Not quite as fun as I imagined it would be. The slight steampunkishness" seemed to appeal to me at first
date: and the idea of battling airships stirred my imagination somewhat. The mechanics of the game are fairly straightforward
recommended: and ultimately there is not much to it: run around the ship (in third person view) either manning weapons (in first person view) or repairing various stations/components; you earn credits/currency by ending each battle with as much cargo as possible
hoursPlayed: and you can then purchase upgrades for your ship for the next mission. There is the beginning of an interesting game concept here. I understand that the developer is probably now more focused on their online version of this game; this is partially evidenced by them renaming this one "Flight of the Icarus" to distinguish it from the multiplayer "Guns of Icarus Online" (although this game originally claimed to have a "multiplayer" option as well
voteText: it has recently been updated to remove that option from the main screen). I've observed some fairly enthusiastic feedback for the online product
helpfulPercent: but I haven't tried it myself so it's not possible to provide an effective comparison. This edition definitely has a "freshman" feel to it
votesHelpful: with not much in terms of depth and refinement of features. I obtained it at a highly discounted price
votesTotal: so I'm not holding it against them. Generally
votesFunny: I wouldn't bother -- tons of other indie games with more to offer."

This game is a unique first person ship-combat simulator where you fight off waves of incoming pirates which damage your ship's hull, baloon, engines, and cargo bay. I find the game highly enjoyable and if more people played it's multiplayer option i'm sure it could be great!

The temptation when looking at Guns of Icarus (this game) is to compare it with its superior sequel, Guns of Icarus Online (which is probably the game you've heard about anyway, so go check it out too); but while Guns of Icarus features less sophisticated gameplay and graphics, if you give it a chance it reveals itself as a little gem in its own right that most larger, more sophisticated games could learn from.

First, there's the way it guides the player without detracting from your control of play. Guns of Icarus has no tutorial stage where you're forced to push the buttons you're told to push. Rather, whenever something new first comes up -- be it another part of the ship is on fire or you first mount a given type of gun -- the game pauses and tells you everything you need to know about it. Once you're done absorbing the info, you unpause and it won't bother you about it again. This allows Guns of Icarus to stay out of your way as a player while still saving you from needing any sort of manual. Furthermore, the player is allowed to ease their way into the game simply by being provided levels at all stages of difficulty, which brings us to the next thing.

Second, there's the multitude of paths. A campaign consists of a series of flights between map locations taking you from the starting location to a final showdown on the other end of the map, and at almost every location you can choose between multiple locations to go to next. The flights have various degrees of difficulty, allowing you to choose a path that starts easy enough to build up strength and then step up the difficulty whenever you're ready. If you survive a level you can continue to the next, but if you also keep your cargo hold from serious damage you can get better guns and armor. Naturally, harder levels offer better upgrades for keeping your cargo intact, to make it worth the added difficulty of getting those upgrades; so if you take a harder path and excel, you'll be better equipped for the final showdown. And of course, different flights show you different pieces of the story, which brings us to the yet another thing.

Third, there's the exposition. Guns of Icarus has almost no plot, but is full to the brim with story. Rather than using or abusing cutscenes, each location features a postcard-like combination of an almost impressionist oil painting of the place in question and a snippet of an entry from the captain's log (which reads more like a diary, actually). For as minimalist as they are these give you potent glimpses into the world of the Icarus and the life of her captain, and together weave a tale of peoples lost in a hostile world, of their struggle to survive, and of pressing on with no destination save the next step in the journey. It's a somber tale, but the good, pensive kind of somber that leaves you pondering how you'd manage in such rough times and wondering if you can tell if people who seem cold and hardened aren't really just weary of being desperate for so long. The end of the game also (minor spoiler...) seems to nod subtly to the Greek legend of Icarus, which should please the classically minded (I know it pleased me).

To be fair to people thinking of buying Guns of Icarus, here are some obvious things from Guns of Icarus Online that you won't find in the original here (at least in single-player mode): companions to help keep your ship in the air, the ability to steer/pilot the ship, multiple ships to choose from and multiple ammo modes for each gun. Oh, and Steam Achievements, if you really gotta have those. There is also less variety of music in this game, and the graphics aren't quite as polished. The gameplay here consists almost entirely of running from gun to gun trying to shoot down wave after wave of World War I style fighter planes and still have time to repair your airship, but it does take some tactical strategy to succeed. To be fair, the sequel was just doing what every good sequel should: build upon, expand upon and improve upon its predecessor without spoiling the legacy or trampling on anything important. It would, nonetheless, be a mistake to focus only on what the original Guns of Icarus doesn't have, without appreciating what it does so well; and if you prefer just to shoot down waves of enemies, of if you really like a somber story told in postcards, you might actually like it a little better.

In short, while you should definitely check out the sequel Guns of Icarus Online if you're interested in either of these games, the original Guns of Icarus is a brilliant example of a well-designed game and may still be worth your time.

You run around using turrets on your floating ship, shooting down incoming planes.  When you get damaged, you have to go and repair (click) on section(s) of your ship.  When the level finished (it has travelled a certain distance) you get an option to upgrade a weapon and switch the turrets on your ship.   You then choose what route to follow for the next mission"

recommended: but it is not going to stay on your hard drive for long.\n"
